title: Switching mobile phone firms must be simpler, says Ofcom
text:

Wed, Jul 29, 2015, 10:36 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 54 mins Switching mobile phone firms must be simpler, says Ofcom By Dan Hyde | Telegraph – 35 minutes ago Print 
A new switching facility will let consumers to keep their old numbers when they change provider 
Mobile phone users will be able to switch deals and keep their numbers without telling their old providers under a move by watchdogs designed to create a price war. 
The new switching facility was announced yesterday by Ofcom, which is concerned that companies are making it “unnecessarily hard” to switch to a better deal. 
People waste an estimated £6bn a year by staying on the wrong contract for their needs, according to industry analysis, with many paying as much as £60 a month for a smartphone contract. Just 6 per cent of people switch each year to get a better deal. 
• BT home phone customer? You could be paying hundreds for a £10 phone 
Ofcom said it was concerned that people found the transfer process too complex and time consuming. 
Currently, users must obtain a code from their old provider, and take it to their new one a process made more difficult by call centre queues. 
In a public consultation initiated yesterday the telecoms watchdog said people should have to make only one phone call to move to a new provider. 
The rest would be handled behind the scenes. Sharon White, the chief executive of Ofcom, said: “Consumers should be able to switch their mobile providers with minimum hassle to take advantage of the best deals on the market.” 
Guy Anker, the managing editor of MoneySavingExpert.com, said: “It’s vital the system is significantly simplified so customers only need to deal with the new provider as they do on so many other types of switching. Only then will people have the true confidence to get themselves a better deal.” 
Ofcom data showed that rates of mobile switching fell from 9 per cent to 6 per cent between 2013 and 2014. 
If customers were more likely to switch, companies would be forced to offer better deals, it explained. 
“Seamless switching processes can help promote competition,” the regulator said in its consultation document. “If switching is easy, providers face strong incentives to provide good-value, high-quality services. They may also compete to offer innovative services with the aim of winning customers from competitors.” 
A spokesman for O2 said the current system worked well for most customers, but welcomed “dialogue with Ofcom on where improvements can be made”.
